title: Will Russia execute and/or sponsor a low or higher level cyber attack against networks owned by a US entity between 19 September 2017 and 30 November 2017?
preds: As the special counsel's investigation moves forward and reveals more information about activities of Russian intelligence against the U.S., we may see more aggressive Russia-based cyber "active measures."
What are cyber operatives linked to Russian intelligence up to now? What are their future plans for "active measures" against America and U.S. entities?
In recent cyber activities against the U.S. and other nations, Russian intelligence may have been "preparing the battlefield" for future operations.
The USG and U.S. companies and entities reportedly continue to be somewhat unprepared for future cyber attacks.

It seems to be just a matter of time (and circumstances) until Putin, his oligarchs and Russian intelligence (or their proxies) launch more cyber attacks, "active measures" and cyber influence operations against the U.S.
As the special counsel closes in on USG Executive Branch persons regarding their contacts with Russian intelligence and oligarchs, more Russia-based cyber attacks could occur.

Recent news reports contain some related OSINT regarding cyber activities against the U.S. by Pres. Putin and Russian intelligence:

Cyber-related "active measures," influence operations and penetration of U.S. society by Russian intelligence and the Putin administration are sure to continue -- including during the time frame of this GJ question (through Nov. 30).

Twitter's banning of ads from RT and Sputnik was referred to by Director of the Information and Press Department of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, Maria Zharakova, as an assault on freedom of speech. She also implicated the US government in the move. Given that InfoWars received a similar notice from Facebook, it's likely tech companies are beginning to crack down on the conspiratorial narratives such sites promote. Spreading disinformation is a cornerstone of Russian disinformation, so it's likely the Kremlin will begin to fall back on other tactics -- such as cyber attacks -- to propagate its information war. Having said that, Russia has been known to use proxies to obscure its role in cyber war in the past; while it's likely a cyber attack will occur, it might not necessarily be traced back to Russia by January 31 2018.

Sanctions are moving forward against Russian entities in response to cyber activities, covert influence operations, "meddling" and various types of penetration of American society (and U.S. government/state governments).

Russian intelligence's cyber activities could include sponsoring a cyber attack by North Korea. According to news reports, Russia recently began helping North Korea with internet connectivity.
I agree with other forecasters that Russian intelligence and Pres. Putin might be "laying low" right now as far as cyber attacks -- for a number of reasons.

The biggest source of uncertainty for these types of questions lies in how GJ interprets the question - for example what threshold of evidence they will require to consider an attack state-sponsored or executed. Looking over FireEye's past reports, they often use fairly equivocal language when talking about whether a hack or hacking group is state backed.
Do the Putin administration and Russian intelligence want to ratchet up the cyber conflict with the U.S.?
Russian intelligence personnel and their cyber operatives seem to be having much success in their "active measures" targeting American society.

I broke the question down into a simpler question: In any given year how many reported cyber attacks on the US will be perpetrated by Russian attackers? I figure about 1. The time period given is exactly 20% of the year.

Using a benchmark method (above or below 50%)
low prob due to near deadline <50%
higher prob due to loose parameters for question to resolve = 50%
higher prob due to ease of access of corporate / govt systems >50%
higher due to sheer # of actors that could perpetrate hack >60%
low due to difficulty in attaching responsibility to Russian government <50
low prob because reporting hacks seems to be slow, after-the-fact and hard to pin down exactly what happened and especially where it originated. <40

Because 1) The long-term of Russia's strategy aims to re-gain a status as global power, in order to secure its borders trough a strong influence into its neighbor affairs, contend NATO expansion and control comercial routes. A cyber attack or any other "hybrid" action must advance this purpose. Defeating H.Clinton fulfill this requirement. But today, in the middle of the investigation of the Russia involvement in the last election, when all the world direct its sight to them when something like a cyber attack happened, when the way the government operates is becoming to light, it seems useless take actions like a cyberattack. 2) The current crisis provoked by North Korea has force Russia face directly USA about how to deal whit the treat. Until now, the way has been diplomatic talking. Russia seems really concern about the outcome of the crisis. It means, that Putin are not maneuvering as he is doing in Sirya, in order to bargain with the USA. So, a cyber attack only can cut the diplomatic way, which appears as Putin's strategy in this affair.3) Russia is trying to negotiate with the west, using  Sirya and Ukraine as bargaining chip. It is no time for a cyber attack
